title: Using tls instead of http server causes express to crash
Fix typos in req.accepts comments.
body:
* "mime type" -> "MIME type"
* "delimted" -> "delimited"

Basically fixes a bunch of grammatical errors in the `req.accepts` docs.

title: path specific error handler not called
Misleading link on http://expressjs.com/
body:
On http://expressjs.com/...

When you click Guide on the navbar, it takes you to http://expressjs.com/guide/error-handling.html, which I think is misleading. I thought it was the first part of the guide, but really it's the 4th out of 8 parts.

title: Add "set" Method to "Router"
body:
Hey guys,
I think it would be nice to be able to set options to single Routes. For example one can set a default layout for the handlebars rendering engine with 
```javascript
app.set('view options', { layout: 'main' });
```
or with 
```javascript
app.engine(".hbs", handlebars({
	defaultLayout: "main", 
}));
```

When using a ``express.Router()`` for example with ``app.use("/admin", adminRouter)`` it would be nice to be able to use something like
```javascript
adminRouter.set('view options', { layout: 'adminMain' });
```
to prevent using 
```javascript
res.render('home', {layout: "adminMain"});
```
for every call to ``res.render``

Thanks

-André-

title: Don't call request.end() twice on a HEAD that redirects
body: A res.redirect() on a HEAD request ended up calling end() twice. (I noticed this because in jsdom context it results in a "Called dispose() after dispose()" error from contextify.) Includes a test.

title: Please document the app property in the request object.
body: I think It would be useful to know by reading the [API docs](http://expressjs.com/4x/api.html), that there's an `app` property in the request object on every middleware.

title: test
body: test

title: Identify if request is local or remote.
body:
Hello,

I am using Express.js in a web app. During development I want to include one thing. In production, I want to do another. For this reason, I need to identify whether a request was made locally or remotely. Essentially, I want to have:
```
var isLocalRequest = // something;
```

How do you do this with Express?

title: Better support for promises in controllers
express.static() only routes over one directory.
body:
I am new to express and Node.js, but I have a long history in Java, and I recently had this issue.

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/28143419/express-static-keeps-routing-my-files-from-the-route

I am making a feature request to support static routing over more than one domains. That way, I don't have to create a static route for all my css, js, and other static folders. So I could do something like:

    app.use(express.static(__dirname + '/public');

and then access /js/script.js, /css/style.css and etc.

title: req.params cannot handle encoded #
body:
When getting a url parameter using req.params, for example the `example` parameter is set as:
    `one%20two%23three`
`req.params.example`, or `req.param('example')`, will only return
    `one two`
and not
    `one two#three`

title: Slows down after serving files for a while.
body:
I'm using expressjs 4.10.7 as a file server with the ```static``` middleware and I've noticed that after a few days it becomes extremely slow at serving files and I have to restart express to get back to normal speed.

Is this a known issue? Is there something I can do to avoid it?

title: Duplicate request
Reject routes containing an unescaped space character
body:
At the moment, when the developer provides a route path containing raw characters that must escaped by HTTP clients, for example a space character, the route is registered by express even though it will never match any request (URL):

```js
var app = express();
app.get('/foo bar', function(req, res) { /* ... */ });

// clients send `GET /foo%20bar`, server responds with 404
```

Such situation is difficult to troubleshoot, especially if the invalid character was included by mistake.

I am proposing to modify Express and/or path-to-regexp to print a warning when a string path argument contains characters that will be always sent in the encoded form by HTTP clients. [RFC3986](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986#section-2) allows some characters to be sent either encoded or unencoded. Such characters should be accepted as valid (no error/warning).

In other words, only the following characters may be present in the unencoded form:

 - Unreserved characters: `ALPHA / DIGIT / "-" / "." / "_" / "~"`
 - Reserved characters: `":" / "/" / "?" / "#" / "[" / "]" / "@" / "!" / "$" / "&" / "'" / "(" / ")" / "*" / "+" / "," / ";" / "="`

@dougwilson thoughts? StrongLoop can contribute the change, I just want to check with you that such change will be accepted.

I was initially thinking that express should throw an error instead of printing a warning, but since such change may be considered as breaking backwards compatibility, it's probably better to stay with the warning.

/cc @PradnyaBaviskar

title: route can not use in chinese
body:
work good/articles/:type(%E8%B6%8B%E5%8A%BF|%E8%A7%82%E7%82%B9|%E6%A1%88%E4%BE%8B)

wrong:   /articles/:type(趋势|观点|案例)?

title: req.params is an array in 3.x
body:
Documentation states:
> This property is an array containing properties mapped to the named route "parameters". For example if you have the route /user/:name, then the "name" property is available to you as req.params.name. This object defaults to {}.

Last sentence makes me expect that it is not an array. But it is, which makes some libraries, like `lodash` for example, handle it unexpectedly.

On the other hand, one dealing with routes in regular expression format would probably find the length property handy. Any ideas for the workaround? Is it a bug?

title: Error handlers missing next param
Help with best practice using router param and router routes
Add support for ES6 Generator Functions in release 5.0
body:
Hey Everyone, 
                      Over the week I forked express and added generator function support for middleware and request handlers. It was only a few lines of code, [here is the commit](https://github.com/kenrick/express/commit/8dac72bc9b11a71ed52a54bf35768d2ead912238), and I recorded my results in this [blog post](http://kenrick.me/blog/es6-generators-in-express.html).

Would it be possible to add support in the next release of Express.

title: case sensitive routing not working
body: When I write `app.set('case sensitive routing', true);`, the server still works when receiving requests for /Path and /path even when the route is `router.get('/path/:value([a-z]+)', router_handler);`. Also I'd like `value` only allows lower letters, but it receives upper letters. What am I doing wrong?.

title: sending 204 No Content should not require an empty object
body:
when sending 204 the client still receives 200.

```js
res.status(204).send();
```

results in a 200 code 

but when you pass in an empty object it suddenly handles the result as 204

```js
res.status(204).send({});
```

this seems completely against all logic, as an empty object is still an object, and not No Content.

or am I jumping the gun too quickly and forgetting something here?
